title: mMRC (Modified Medical Research Council) Dyspnea Scale
description: Stratifies severity of dyspnea in respiratory diseases, particularly COPD, based on functional disability

parameters.name: dyspnea_grade
parameters.description: Patient's functional limitation due to dyspnea based on activities that trigger breathlessness

result.name: mmrc_grade
result.description: mMRC dyspnea grade indicating severity of functional limitation

ranges.interpretation: Dyspnea only with strenuous exercise. Normal exercise tolerance with minimal functional impairment. Patient can perform most activities without significant breathlessness.
Dyspnea when hurrying or walking up a slight hill. Slight limitation in activities involving exertion or walking uphill. Generally good functional capacity for daily activities.
Walks slower than people of the same age because of dyspnea, or has to stop for breath when walking at own pace on level ground. Moderate limitation affecting walking speed and endurance.
Stops for breath after walking 100 yards (91 m) or after a few minutes on level ground. Significant limitation in walking distance. Severely impaired exercise tolerance.
Too dyspneic to leave house or breathless when dressing or undressing. Severe disability with breathlessness at rest or with minimal activity. Housebound due to dyspnea.

references: Mahler DA, Wells CK. Evaluation of clinical methods for rating dyspnea. Chest. 1988 Mar;93(3):580-6. doi: 10.1378/chest.93.3.580.

Bestall JC, Paul EA, Garrod R, Garnham R, Jones PW, Wedzicha JA. Usefulness of the Medical Research Council (MRC) dyspnoea scale as a measure of disability in patients with chronic obstructive pulmonary disease. Thorax. 1999 Jul;54(7):581-6. doi: 10.1136/thx.54.7.581.

formula: Single categorical assessment based on functional limitation due to dyspnea
notes: Walking assessment should be performed on level ground
Correlates with health-related quality of life measures
Used as component of BODE Index for COPD prognosis
Part of GOLD guidelines for COPD assessment
Not meant to independently guide clinical management decisions
Should be assessed at baseline and during follow-up visits
May indicate potential morbidity and mortality risk in respiratory diseases
